questiontext.text:
A golf club is swung with an average angular acceleration, $$\small\alpha$$, of 2 rad.s-2.

What is the angular velocity, $$\small\omega$$, (in both degree and radian based units) of the club when it strikes the ball at the end of a 0.99 seconds swing?




{1:NUMERICAL:=2:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s

{1:NUMERICAL:=114.6:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} degree/s

(Give your answers correct to 1.d.p, and use your rounded answer from the first part of the question to answer the second part of the question)

(Question ID #1).

generalfeedback.text:
It may be helpful to recall the following concepts regarding angular motion over time, $$t$$:

Angular displacement, $$\small\theta=\omega\cdot t$$

Angular velocity, $$\small\omega=\frac{d\theta }{dt}=\alpha\cdot t$$

Angular acceleration, $$\small\alpha=\frac{d^2\theta }{dt^2}=\frac{d\omega }{dt}$$

These parameters can be measured in either rad or degree based units, where,

1 rad = $$\small(\frac{180}{\pi })$$ degrees, and

1 degree = $$\small(\frac{\pi}{\180 })$$ rad.


Therefore, in the case of this question, applying $$\small\omega=\alpha\cdot t$$ gives:

$$\small\omega=2\time0.99=2$$ rad/s

Multiplying by $$\small(\frac{180}{\pi })$$ gives:

$$\small\omega=114.6$$ degrees/s

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image adapted from 'http://www.wickedstick.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/physics_golf_swing_1-222x300.png'

hint.text:
HINT

Remember that angular velocity, $$\small\omega$$, is the rate of change of angular displacement with respect to time.

Remember also that angular acceleration, $$\small\alpha$$, is the rate of change of angular velocity with respect to time.

questiontext.text:

(Give your answers correct to 1.d.p, and use your rounded answer from the first part of the question to answer the second part of the question)

generalfeedback.text:
It may be helpful to recall the following concepts regarding angular motion over time, $$t$$:

Angular displacement, $$\small\theta=\omega\cdot t$$

Angular velocity, $$\small\omega=\frac{d\theta }{dt}=\alpha\cdot t$$

Angular acceleration, $$\small\alpha=\frac{d^2\theta }{dt^2}=\frac{d\omega }{dt}$$

These parameters can be measured in either rad or degree based units, where,

1 rad = $$\small(\frac{180}{\pi })$$ degrees, and

1 degree = $$\small(\frac{\pi}{\180 })$$ rad.


Therefore, in the case of this question, applying $$\small\omega=\alpha\cdot t$$ gives:

$$\small\omega=1.3\time0.83=1.1$$ rad/s

Multiplying by $$\small(\frac{180}{\pi })$$ gives:

$$\small\omega=63$$ degrees/s
